bibl.title: Letter from R.C. Derivaux to Henry Rose Carter, April 12, 1922

div1.p: Derivaux tells Carter of his activities over the past three years. He is now in private practice and teaching at Vanderbilt Medical School.

div1.head: Letter from R.C. Derivaux to Henry Rose Carter, April 12, 1922
div1.opener:
Miscellaneous
Derivaux
DR. R. C. DERIVAUX
DOCTORS' BUILDING
NASHVILLE, TENNESSEE
April 12, 1922.
My dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
It would put me to considerable embarassment to
try to remember anything that has given me more genuine
pleasure than that of your letter of a few days ago. I too,
while shamefully remiss in my writing, have thought of you
very often and we speak often of you at home, but my own
failure to write to you has been due largely to lack of
any but approximate knowledge as to where you were. I have
been hearing of you at intervals; Dr. West has been able to
bring back little fragments of gossip from Washington and
elsewhere and has told me at various times that you were in
South America, that you had suffered a very serious accident,
that you were again travelling, etc., but at no time have I
had any other than very vague idea as to where you were or
what or how you were doing.

From your letter, however, it is plain that the
term “waiting orders” has a number of meanings. You seem to
have been into things which have long gone begging for the
doing and should be most helpful. As to the malaria abstracts,
it is high time that the chaff and the grain be sifted apart,
and as for the Yellow Fever history, the thing seems almost
Providential. To go in for that is a particularly graceful
activity for the International Health Board to foster, and to
get you do do it is simply fine; it is superfluous for me to
add that you are probably the only man who is familiar with
the major part of the western hemisphere zone at first hand
and has participated in the solution of the epidemiology of
the condition; I know that you will enjoy the accomplishment
of the task, and I am am equally sure that when it will have
been completed it is certain to be a source of real pride
to you. I think it is just splendid.

As to my own work, I hardly know where or how to
begin. I entered private practice here in July, 1919, at the
close of my Service detail, taking up the class of work in which
I was best qualified, ie., the laboratory side. I have worked
very hard, and I have made a certain amount of progress; if
success is to be measured in terms of bank balances or real
estate holdings, I am still at my beginnings, but if on the
other hand, friendships, confidence, etc., count for anything,
my time has not been wasted. I have made more money since I
have been at work here than I have ever made before, though it
has cost much more to “carry on”. Each year has shown definite
gains and I have much to be very grateful for as there are
many other and older men here who have not fared so well.
I am still doing laboratory work almost exclusively, “almost”
in that I have taken charge of a few medical cases; I am
getting more and more interested in the field of Internal
Medicine, particularly in the side of metabolism (diabetes,
hypertension, etc), and the cases that I have taken so far
have belonged almost exclusively to that class. Whether at
some time in the future I will go into medicine is as yet
not determined, though I find it very attractive.

I am teaching two courses at Vanderbilt Medical School,
ie., Preventive Medicine and Clinical Pathology; the first
is a lecture course to the Senior class, some thirty lectures
in all, covering (?) the entire subject; I am probably open
to the criticism in this that malaria and typhoid get by far
the best of it, and Vital Statistics (shades of Trask!) some
rather shabby treatment. The Clinical Pathology course is
a laboratory course to the Sophomores and it is too heavy,
-there is no “probably” about it this time, in parasitology.
While one course, the Prev. Med., is a Fall course and the other
comes in the Spring, I dont think I can carry the two any
longer; the laboratory course calls for four hours a day for
five days a week, six weeks, and, while I am being paid for the
time, it is far too burdensome. I hope to get relieved next
year and will gladly accept an unpaid assistantship instead of
heading the course. The job, besides, ought to be the official
attachment of a full-time man by whom collateral research might
be carried on. Lord knows, there is plenty of room for it in
connection with some of our southern problems.

Speaking of research, however, I am almost ashamed to
admit that malaria and its literature has gotten precious
little of my time in the past few years. I have been studying
chemistry and physiology almost to the exclusion of everything
else, and besides, I have seen so little malaria that it seems
almost a curiosity.

I would be doing neither you nor the truth justice, if
I left you with the impression that Nashville and my work have
been so completely absorbing that everything else has been
subordinated. I have been homesick just lots of times and I
have missed the Service and its associations, even the asinini-
ties of the inspired Bureau and others whom I might but wont
mention by name, seem, -in retrospect, to be sort of glossed
over with a few lovable attributes. I have certainly missed
our field trips, the “talk” part that is, for I detested the
rest of it, as I have told you, probably only too often. I have
though, found here a lot of things that I have wanted; I live in
one place, I know a lot of people, I have accumulated a few
books, and, in short, I like it, but there are days when I miss
many things of the Service life. I cant say that I have ever
had cause to regret my change though some of my best friends
seem mighty inaccessible and faraway.

Your letter reached me on the day of one of the farewell
dinners given to Dr. Olin West and when I told him that night
of your letter and of its message to him, he was immensely
pleased to have been remembered by you. He asked me to convey
his good regards to you and to thank you for your message. I
am deeply sorry at his going; he has been one of my closest
friends here and often my advisor, but the loss to Dr. Wests
personal friends, who are legion, does not compare with the
loss to the State of Tennessee. To me he has stood out as one
of the best, if not the best State Health Officer in the South,
and I know that he has done almost single-handed, work that
compares very favorably with wealthier or more liberal States.
He is being succeeded by his old predecessor, Dr. Lillard, an
out-and-out political doctor of the most typical variety. It
is a great pity and much of the most valuable rural work that
has just been begun and is still in its infancy is certain to
be utterly lost. Dr. West goes into his new work with all of the
good wishes of a lot of fine people, but also with the deepest
of regrets on the part of those who are familiar with what he has
accomplished.

Good old friend, I find that in starting to write you a
latter, I have come dangerously near undertaking a book. There
is still much I should like to write of, but it is growing late
and there will be other letters. My Mother and Sister, -both of
whom are in excellent health, ask me to convey to you their
good regards. Thanks again for your letter. Remember me warmly
to Miss Laura and to Henry.
